newsitem.title: ESTONIA: HANSA, HOIU SAY STATE FUNDS POORLY MANAGED.
newsitem.headline: HANSA, HOIU SAY STATE FUNDS POORLY MANAGED.

text.p: Hansapank and Hoiupank on Tuesday criticised the poor management of state funds in an open letter to the prime minister and proposed more efficient methods for investing public finance.
The two leading banks said in a statement the state keeps too much money - 1.5 billion kroons - in demand deposits, although it could invest it differently to earn additional revenues.
The banks estimated the state budget would need only 150-300 million kroons in demand deposits.
The banks said it would then be possible to pay back at least one billion kroons in foreign debt, which would save 30 million kroons in annual interest payments.
If the state would not like to pay back foreign debt, it could chane its funds from demand deposits to time deposits, where it could earn an additional 50 million kroons, the banks said.
They added that investments into money market funds or commercial papers were also lurative options which the state should explore.
Most state funds are deposited in Uhispank , Estonia's second largest commercial bank.
